title: 111_s4022
content: The Act titled "Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010" addresses the Department of Defense policy regarding homosexuality in the Armed Forces. The Secretary of Defense initiated a Comprehensive Review on the Implementation of a Repeal of 10 U.S.C. 654 to assess the impacts on military readiness, effectiveness, and cohesion, as well as provide guidance on conduct and policies. The Comprehensive Review on the Implementation of a Repeal of 10 U.S.C. 654 includes determining changes to policies and regulations, recommending changes to the Uniform Code of Military Justice, monitoring legislative proposals, evaluating workforce climate and military effectiveness, and addressing ongoing issues. The ongoing litigation involving 10 U.S.C. 654 will be evaluated, with amendments taking effect 60 days after certain conditions are met, including receiving a required report and a written certification from the President, Secretary of Defense, and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The Department of Defense has prepared necessary policies and regulations to exercise discretion provided by amendments. Implementation of these policies must align with military standards. Section 654 of title 10, United States Code, remains in effect until all requirements and certifications are met. Section 654 of title 10, United States Code, remains in effect until all requirements and certifications are met. The amendments made by this section do not require benefits that violate the Defense of Marriage Act or create a private cause of action. Chapter 37 of title 10 is amended by striking section 654. Upon the effective date established by subsection (b), section 571 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1994 is amended by striking subsections (b), (c), and (d).
